title: Effective Communication Skills for Managers
headline: Learn the most effective communication skills for managers, with this free online effective communication skills course.
description: With this free online Effective Communication Skills for Managers course, you will learn how to boost your workplace communication skills. Communication skills are essential for all major tasks in the workplace, from understanding employeesâ€™ concerns and requests to ensuring that objectives are clear. In just 3 hours, you can have the confidence and clarity of communication that you need to connect with your staff and excel as a manager.

courseDescription:
The course begins by showing you in a step-by-step manner how you can successfully prepare for and engage in any difficult conversation you may be faced with in a workplace situation. You will learn about the rules of communication, the importance of non-verbal communication and how to develop effective listening skills. You will then learn how to build rapport with your colleagues so that you can start to lead the conversation. You will also learn how influence works and how to strengthen your skills of influence and persuasion.

Next, you will learn how to plan and develop an effective presentation. The course will show you how to overcome nervousness and deliver presentations naturally, whether you are speaking at a small team meeting or presenting to an audience of hundreds. Finally, you will learn about the key communication skills needed for successful team meetings. You will also learn about the importance of creating and distributing minutes of the meeting that accurately describe what was discussed at the meeting, any action points that were agreed upon, and who has responsibility for these action points.

If you want to strengthen your managerial skills, or are hoping to become a manager, then this is the course for you. Every manager needs these skills, and with this short course, you can gain them in just 3 hours. By the end of the course, you will have the ability to speak clearly and effectively. More importantly, you will have gained confidence that will really help you in your professional life. That is a great reward, so get started and by the end of the week you will have given yourself a great boost.

Start Course Now

Once you have completed this certificate course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison certificate is:

Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital certificate: a downloadable certificate in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked certificate, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked certificate in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

slides:
• Learning Outcomes
  • Having completed this course, the learner will be able to:
  •  
    • Identify the risks and rewards of difficult workplace conversations.
    • Examine the rules of communication.
    • Describe how you can build a rapport with colleagues to lead the conversation.
  • Head in the Sand
  • Difficult? Don't Worry!
  • Welcome! Oo you need to have a difficult conversation with someone soon? Nervous about how they wit react? Don't know where to start? A conversation can be difficult for numerous reasons. Common examples include:
    • Discussions about poor performance or inappropriate behaviour.
    • Giving bad news, such as a missed promotion.
    • Making a complaint.
    • Sharing an unpopular decision.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • If this is the kind of conversation you are facing, don't worry you can take your head out of the sand. Just work through this short topic and you'll soon REAP the rewards of well prepared, structured and managed difficult conversations.

  • We're Not Robots
  •  
    How dull would it be if we were all the same?

    Ever tried speaking at a constant pace, without varying your tone of voice? How about speaking whilst standing or sitting rigid and still? Difficult - perhaps impossible! Wouldn't feel natural, would it?

    Thankfully we're not robots. The way we move our body and the way we say things adds meaning and emphasis to the words we speak This invaluable gift, which helps to form our individuality, is called non-verbal communication.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Lesson Summary
    • Procrastination - "I can't do this now. I'll do it tomorrow".
    • Trivia spotting - "Look at this error, and this one, and another one".
    • Dodging responsibility - "I'm not very good at this. Someone else will sort it out".
  • The following are potential risks when having to make a difficult conversation:
    • Personal embarrassment if the conversation goes wrong.
    • Uneasiness if strong emotions are shown.
    • Overwhelmed if too much information is shared.
  • The following are potential rewards when having to make a difficult conversation:
    • Find new solutions to problems.
    • Take control of the situation.
    • Improve teamwork or personal relationships.

  • Learning Outcomes
  • Having completed this course, the learner will be able to:
  •  
    • Examine how to develop and deliver effective presentations.
    • Discuss how to chair a meeting and write up the minutes of a meeting.
    • Describe strategies you can use to influence others.
  • Perfect Preparation
  • The annual Conference for Clay Creatures is coming up and our gang has been asked to present 10-minutes on the importance of clay today. Is this great news? Would your first thought be elation or fear and dread?

    Which statement best reflects your initial reaction if asked to prepare for a similar task? Select your response.
    • Confident - Let me at it. I can't wait to get started!
    • Unprepared - With the right preparation I could do a good job.
    • Nervous - If I can control my nerves I might get through it successfully.
    • Panicked - I wouldn't know where to start and would rather run in the opposite direction.

    Great Who did you think of? Ben Affleck, Ben Stiller, Ben Kingsley? Perhaps your Ben is more obscure. That doesn't matter Just remember what Ben does. Ben acts.

    We'll come back to the relevance of this later. In the meantime, let's press on.

  • My Biggest Influence
  • Many of us are not natural influences. We would rather follow the crowd than assert our position. But good ideas should always be shared

    And helping others to understand your point of view is the first step to making a positive change. Think for a moment. Who has had or is the biggest influence on you? How do they do it?

  • Lesson Summary
  • Given that it is difficult to hold an audience's attention for more than 20 minutes, the generally accepted maximum number of key points to cover in a presentation of that length: Seven (7) key points.
  • Steps to make the PERFECT presentation:
    • Pinpoint your purpose.
    • Empathise with your audience.
    • Research your content.
    • Filter your content.
    • Enhance your content.
    • Cue cards - Use them if needed.
    • Tick list - Logistics of presentation.
  • The following are powerful non-verbal communication tools:
    • Speak up but don't shout.
    • Convey your enthusiasm through your tone of voice, expressions and gestures.
    • Look at your audience - Catch and hold people's gazes briefly.
